div1.p: [Carter] requests information from Guiteras regarding yellow fever blood samples.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Juan Guiteras, December 28, 1918
div1.p:
Tell me something of the blood picture of yellow fever, in
the beginning and later on. Carroll states (Page 943, Modern
Medecine) “The leukocytes are practically normal in number and
appearance. In a small proportion of the cases a moderate de-
gree of polymorphonuclear leukocytosis can be demonstrated.” He
repeats the statement on Page 946. adding that the polymorpho-
nuclear “are frequently increased.”

I presume Carroll's statement is based on work at Las Animas
of which you should be cognizant.

The normal blood picture is assumed by Seidelin in one of
his publications and, “with slight leukocytosis,” is asserted by
Balfour.

At Ancon Hospital we did not use the blood picture as furn-
ishing aid to diagnosis. I think, regarded it as normal. I
noticed that of the number I examined, looking for malaria para-
sites, there was no leukopenia or leukocytosis which would be re-
marked with out counting. Of course, I was not looking for such.

Yet, in a monograph on this subject, which I read at Bahia,
and in which a number of counts were recorded, leukopenia was
marked and in cases extreme. He used a Hayem instrument, which
is less accurate--unless in skillful hands--than a Sahli, the one
-2-
usually used.

One naturally turns to you for an authoritative pronunciamento
on matters connected with yellow fever. Therefore I ask, what are
the facts of the blood picture?
